metadata.title: Kabuki Syndrome  Occupational Therapy
anatomical location body part affected: Multiple systems of the body can be affected, including the central nervous system (CNS), the face, the musculoskeletal system, the endocrine system, the gastrointestinal system, the cardiovascular system, and the renal system
description: Kabuki syndrome (KS) is a rare congenital syndrome characterized by multiple physical and cognitive features.(1) The abnormalities associated with KS vary from individual to individual; however, all those affected have characteristic facial features, with long palpebral fissures (the separation between upper and lower eyelids), everted lower eyelids, and arched eyebrows.(1,2) Individuals with KS typically have some degree of developmental delay and intellectual disability(1) or application of equipment Impairment of ADLs/ IADLsIncrease or maintain independence in ADLs/ IADLsFunctional training _ ADL/IADL training _ _ Through the use of functional activities, promote independence in self-care skills for dressing, grooming, and eating _ _ Use of adaptive or assistive devices and technology as appropriateInitially, break ADL/ IADL tasks down into separate parts; with increased patient tolerance, have the patient perform progressively longer segments of each ADL/ IADL task at a timeParent/caregiver education is important for carryover of ADL/ IADL training into the home environment; provide the patient’s family with a plan for maximizing home safety for ADLs/IADLs with environmental modifications as appropriate  Reduced balance _ _ Reduced strength/ hypotoniaImprove balance in standing, sitting, and dynamic activities _ _ Improve muscle strengthTherapeutic modalities _ Exercise/strength training program _ _ Balance exercisesGradual progression of intensity and duration of exercises to promote overall strengtheningHome program will vary according to patient’s goals and support system . presentation signs and symptoms: Among individuals with KS, there is a large degree of variation in manifestations, which typically affect multiple systems of the body (e.g., musculoskeletal, organs) and impair development (e.g., growth, cognitive);(3) clinical presentation of KS can include:

Infants/children –Dysmorphic facial features (consistent among all individuals with KS) -Long palpebral fissures(1,2) -Everted lower eyelids (may become more prominent with age)(1,2) -Arched, broad eyebrows(1,2) -Short columella (i.e., the lower part of the nasal septum) with a depressed nasal tip(1,2)  -Large, prominent, or cupped ears(1,2) -Ear pits (found at the superior attachment of the pinna to the face; can be unilateral or bilateral)(2) -Hypodontia (i.e., having fewer teeth than normal)(1,2) -Teeth may also be fused or unusually shaped; this increases risk of cavities(1) –Feeding/gastrointestinal issues -Feeding problems in infancy/dysphagia(1,2) -Palatal deformities(1,2) -One third of individuals with KS have overt cleft palates(1) -Increased prevalence of submucous cleft palate (SMCP)(1) -Lip pits (i.e., congenital depressions, often bilateral, on the outer portion of the lower lip)(1) -Lip pits may not cause any functional problems or require any intervention if they are small; however, for larger lip pits complications such as persistent mucous production can occur(1) -Velopharyngeal dysfunction (VPD)(1) -Gastroesophageal reflux (GER)(1) -Chronic diarrhea(1) -Constipation (likely as a result of bowel/abdominal wall hypotonia as well as reduced mobility of intestinal tract)(1) -Anal atresia(2) –Cardiovascular abnormalities -Cardiac abnormalities/congenital heart defects (present in up to 55% of individuals with KS)(1,2,23) -Left-sided  obstructive lesions with aortic coarctation(1) -Atrial septal defect (ASD) and ventricular septal defect (VSD)(1) -Aortic dilatation(1) -Arrhythmia(1) –Neurologic abnormalities -Seizures (affect 15-25%  of individuals with KS)(1,2) -Structural malformations of the CNS(1,2) –Musculoskeletal abnormalities -Hypotonia(1,2) -Joint laxity is present in almost all individuals with KS(1,2) -Hip dislocation occurs with increased frequency in this population(1,25) -Patellar dislocation (often occurs in late childhood or adolescence, especially if there is coexisting obesity)(1) -Short stature(4) -Scoliosis(1,2) -Cervical spine instability(1) -Flat feet(1) -Spinal column abnormalities such as sagittal cleft vertebrae, butterfly vertebrae, narrow intervertebral disc space(2,4) -Brachydactyly V/brachymesophalangy (i.e., short middle bones of the second and fifth fingers and toes)(2) -Clinodactyly (i.e., bending/curvature) of fifth digits(2) –Endocrine/growth abnormalities -Hypoglycemia(1,15) -Growth hormone deficiency(1) -Early onset of puberty in females(1,2,) –Ophthalmic abnormalities -Coloboma (i.e., a hole in one of the structures of the eye such as the retina or iris)(1)  -Strabismus (occurs in 20-50%  of individuals with KS)(1,2) -Ptosis(2) -Cranial nerve palsy(1) -Recurrent eye infections(1) -Often as a result of lacrimal duct stenosis or atresia(1) -Reduced eyelid closure for sleep(1) –Immunity problems -Impaired immunity/increased susceptibility to infection(1,2) -Autoimmune disease(1,2) -Increased risk of idiopathic thrombocytopenic purpura, autoimmune hemolytic anemia, and vitiligo(1) –Skin abnormalities -Fetal finger pads (i.e., prominent, sharply defined fingertip pads)(1,2) -Hirsutism (i.e., excessive hair growth)(1) -Pilomatrixoma (i.e., small subcutaneous nodules; typically found on the scalp)(1) -Small/dystrophic nails –Visceral malformations -Congenital diaphragmatic hernia(1) -Renal tract malformations(1,2,24) -Urinary tract malformations(24) -Anorectal malformations(1) -Biliary atresia(1) –Developmental abnormalities -Developmental delays(1,4) -Mild to moderate intellectual disability (present in over 90% of individuals with KS)(2) -Postnatal growth deficiency (normal birth weight, slow growth over the first year of life)(1,2) -Learning disability(1) -Autistic features(1) –Speech, language, communication abnormalities -Delayed speech and language acquisition(1) -Delayed receptive and expressive language skills(1) -Hypernasal speech due to cleft palate, VPD, or SMCP(1) -Hearing loss; chronic otitis media(1,2)

Adults: in addition to the above-mentioned  abnormalities, adults with KS may also have: –Truncal obesity (begins in adolescence; obesity primarily affecting abdomen/torso)(1) –Confluence of the eyebrows (no longer appear separated)(1) –Deformities of the feet become apparent with overlapping toes, long hallux (first toe), and short fourth and fifth toes (relative to the others)(1) Causes, Pathogenesis, & Risk Factors
contraindications precautions to test: Obtain parental consent prior to evaluating pediatric patients

Family members/caregivers should be involved in both assessment and treatment of pediatric patients as they have a unique perspective and can provide information on the child that cannot be obtained through formal or informal measures

overall contraindications precautions: Observe standard precautions appropriate for systems involved, such as seizure precautions for patients with epilepsy, aspiration precautions for patients with dysphagia, universal precautions with patients with impaired immunity, and cardiac precautions for patients with involvement of the heart

For children with KS, development of an individualized family service plan (IFSP) or individual education plan (IEP) in collaboration with the parents/guardians and early intervention/school personnel is essential to address functional deficits and delayed development in the home and school environment
See specific  Contraindications/precautions to examination   and  Contraindications/precautions   under Assessment/

history of present illness.mechanism of injury or etiology of illne: When was the diagnosis of KS made and by whom? Which systems of the body are affected? -Although KS is present from birth, the diagnosis is typically not made in infancy because there is no definitive diagnostic test for the syndrome and the cardinal facial features are not yet noticeable(1)

course of treatment.medical management: Document medical and surgical management of KS to date. Surgical repair of congenital heart defects is sometimes necessary and often occurs at a very young age (around 1 year)(23)
course of treatment.medications: Determine what medications the physician has prescribed; are they being  Laxatives for constipation(1) Antiseizure medications(2) Antireflux medications(1)
diagnostic tests completed: Diagnostic tests completed: There is no definitive diagnostic test for KS.(1) The diagnosis of KS is made by a physician based on clinical presentation; additional genetic testing may or may not reveal a mutation of the KMT2D  gene.(2) Usual tests completed during the workup for KS include the following:
Microarray analysis to determine if there are any chromosomal abnormalities(1)
Ultrasound of renal tract to identify visceral malformations(1)
Echocardiogram to determine if there are any cardiac abnormalities(1)
Patients with KS who have aortic abnormalities should have annual monitoring for aortic dilatation due to increased risk for dissection(1)
MRI for patients with severe microcephaly, macrocephaly, seizures, or neurological signs of intracranial abnormalities(1)
X-ray  for patients with suspected or confirmed scoliosis(1)
Full blood count (FBC) and thyroid function tests to assess immune system function(1)
course of treatment.alternative therapies: Document any use of home remedies (e.g., ice or heating pack) or alternative therapies (e.g., acupuncture) and whether or not they help Although there is no firm scientific evidence to support the benefit of the following alternative therapies in individuals Music therapy(1) Hippotherapy (i.e., therapeutic horseback riding)(1) Aromatherapy(1) Reflexology(1) Body brushing (i.e., technique used to stimulate nerve endings)(1)
course of treatment.previous therapy: Document whether patient has had speech, occupational, or physical therapy for this or other conditions and what specific treatments were helpful or not helpful

history of present illness.aggravating easing factors: Document any factors that exacerbate or alleviate symptoms and/or functional deficits -Does the patient have hearing or vision difficulties? -Does the patient have speech or language deficits? -Is the patient overly sensitive to sensory stimulation (visual, auditory, or tactile)?
history of present illness.body chart: Use body chart to document location and nature of symptoms
history of present illness.nature of symptoms: Document nature of symptoms (see Presentation/signs & symptoms , above)
history of present illness.rating of symptoms: Use a visual analog scale (V AS) or 0-10 scale to assess symptoms at their best, at their worst, and at the moment (specifically address if pain is present now and how much) -Oucher or FLACC scale for pediatric patients
history of present illness.pattern of symptoms: Document changes in symptoms throughout the day and night, if any (A.M., mid-day,  P.M., night); also document changes in symptoms due to weather or other external variables
history of present illness.other symptoms: Document other symptoms patient may be experiencing that could exacerbate the condition and/or symptoms that could be indicative of a need to refer to physician (e.g., dizziness, bowel/bladder/sexual dysfunction, saddle anesthesia)
history of present illness.respiratory status: Note respiratory status -Does the patient require supplemental oxygen? Tracheostomy tube, nasal cannula, or breathing mask? -Does the patient require mechanical ventilation? -Individuals with KS who have bronchial tract abnormalities and/or a diaphragmatic defect can have recurrent lower respiratory tract infections(1) -There is an increased risk of respiratory tract infections and aspiration pneumonia in individuals with KS due to impaired immunity(1) Document symptoms of psychosocial disturbance or behavioral problems in the patient as well as within the patient’s family (e.g., symptoms of depression, feelings of guilt or isolation, signs of abuse or neglect) and refer family to a social worker or psychologist if necessary -Individuals with KS often have reduced attention span that can result in behavioral problems, especially in school-aged children(1) -Depression and anxiety may develop as a child with KS ages(7)Document hearing ability -Hearing loss has been documented in 30-45%  of children with KS(1) -Hearing loss in children with KS is often the result of recurrent otitis media(1) -All individuals with KS should be evaluated by an audiologist and/or otolaryngologist (ENT)(1) Barriers to learning -Are there any barriers to learning? Yes__ No__ -If Yes, describe ________________________

past medical history.previous history of same similar diagnos: Document history of any other congenital, feeding, or developmental abnormalities. Document if any prior occupational therapy evaluation has been completed; if it has, review past reports
past medical history.comorbid diagnoses: Ask patient about other problems, including diabetes, cancer, heart disease, complications of pregnancy, psychiatric disorders, orthopedic disorders, etc. Celiac disease (gluten intolerance) occurs with increased frequency in individuals with KS(1) See Presentation/Signs and Symptoms  above for other associated comorbidities
past medical history.medications previously prescribed: Obtain a comprehensive list of medications prescribed and/or being taken (including overthe-counter  drugs)
past medical history.other symptoms: Ask patient about other symptoms he/she may be experiencing

social and occupational history.vocation avocation and associated repeti: Vocation/avocation and associated repetitive behaviors, if any -Does the patient currently receive intervention services? If so, are they home, school, hospital, or clinic based? Does the patient attend daycare/preschool/school? -Does the patient live at home? If the patient is an adult, does he or she have a job? -Is the patient involved in the community? Is the patient involved in leisure activities?
social and occupational history.functional limitations assistance with A: Functional limitations/assistance with ADLs/adaptive equipment -Document if and what type of adaptive equipment the patient is using, such as wheelchairs, hearing aids, or glasses -Determine the effect of the patient’s functional deficits on participation in school, social, and occupational activities
social and occupational history.living environment: Obtain information on the patient’s family as well as a description of their living environment. Who is the patient’s primary caregiver(s)? Identify if there are barriers to independence in the home; any modifications necessary?

relevant tests and measures.general: (While tests and measures are listed in alphabetical order, sequencing should be ›Relevant tests and measures: (While tests and measures are listed in alphabetical order, sequencing should be appropriate to patient medical condition, functional status, and setting)
relevant tests and measures.anthropometric characteristics: For adults, note body mass index (BMI); obesity is common, especially after adolescence(1) –Document height and weight; for children with KS, note the child’s percentile on the standardized growth chart. No KS-specific  growth charts are currently available(1) –Researchers in the Netherlands examined the growth data of 39 children with KS and a KMT2D  mutation and concluded that postnatal growth retardation was present in all children. All children also demonstrated a growth deflection during childhood and a diminution of the pubertal growth spurt(27)
relevant tests and measures.assistive and adaptive devices: Assess the patient’s need for and/or use of assistive and adaptive devices –Adaptive feeding equipment -Adaptive utensils -Adaptive plates/bowls -Adaptive cups and/or bottles/nipples –Mobility aids -Ankle-foot  orthoses (AFOs) -Cane -Crutches -Walker -Wheelchair –Toileting equipment -Grab bars next to the toilet -Bedside commode -Raised toilet seat -Elevated foot rest at the toilet –ADL/IADL aids -Reachers; long-handled  equipment -Shoe horn -Elastic shoe laces -Dressing sticks; sock aids -Modified eating utensils -Adaptive toys or play equipment -Adaptive writing instruments -Adaptive kitchen and cooking equipment -Adaptive/ergonomic computer/mouse/keyboard -Text-to-speech  software
relevant tests and measures.balance: Evaluate static and dynamic balance reactions in sitting and standing positions
cardiorespiratory function and endurance: Refer to physician orders regarding physical activity limitations in patients with KS who have congenital heart defects or other cardiac anomalies
relevant tests and measures.circulation: Assess pulse bilaterally; note any discrepancies or abnormalitiesBed mobility and transfers (including toilet and tub transfers) should be assessed to determine the amount of assistance needed for the patient to perform each activity safely –Test static and dynamic functional activities –Timed Up & Go (TUG) test(8) – a measurement of mobility; includes tasks such as standing from a seating position, walking, turning, stopping, and sitting down, all of which are important for independent mobility –FIM – an 18-item,  7-level  ordinal scale(9); WeeFIM for children
relevant tests and measures.gait locomotion: Briefly assess gait –Refer to physical therapy for full gait assessment and intervention if appropriateAssess joint mobility with standard range of movement positions and note clinically relevant features –Patients with KS often exhibit joint laxity(1,2) –Use caution when manipulating joints; individuals with KS have increased risk of dislocation, especially in the hip and knee(1,25)Assess upper extremity grasp and release as well as coordination –Many individuals with KS have hypotonia(1,2)  –Document any congenital abnormalities affecting motor function of the upper extremity; authors of a case study in South Korea documented cleft hand in a child with KS(10)
relevant tests and measures.muscle strength: Manually assess functional upper extremity strength (shoulder, elbow, wrist, and handgrip), trunk strength, and functional lower extremity strength (hip, knee, and ankle) –Manual muscle testing (MMT) to evaluate strength in both upper extremities, including the shoulder, elbow, forearm, wrist, and fingers; do not perform MMT with contracted muscles or muscles with tone and coordination issues –Dynamometer to evaluate hand strength bilaterally –Assess grip force in functional tasks –Assess pinch strengthAssess with standardized neuromotor development tests, such asThis standardized assessment measures gross and fine motor skills of children from birth to 6 years of ageA test of gross and fine motor skills for ages 4-21
relevant tests and measures.posture: Note postural deficits; patients with KS are at risk for scoliosis(1,2) –Assess sitting, standing, and walking posture –Assess the patient’s ability to utilize support (i.e., assistive device or arm support) to improve both standing and walking posture; note posture with/without adaptive equipment –Document static/dynamic posture in both sitting/standing throughout a variety of tasks
relevant tests and measures.range of motion: Assess functional ROM and flexibility of the upper and lower extremities as well as the spineAssess ADLs –FIM testing is appropriate for assessment of ADLs(9) -For children with KS, the WeeFIM is appropriate(11) -The WeeFIM assesses basic daily living and functional skills in children from birth to 7 years of age(11)self-care,  sphincter control, transfers, locomotion, communication, and social cognition(11)Assess patient’s ability to dress and/or cooperate with dressing activities when assisted by parent/caregiverAssess grooming skills -What type of assistance does the patient require for grooming, shaving, brushing the teeth, etc.? -Brushing of the teeth is especially important for patients with KS -An individual with KS may have teeth that are fused or unusually shaped, which increases risk of cavities(1) -If the patient is unable to perform proper oral/dental hygiene tasks, caregiver training is essential to reduce risk of cavities, oral infection, and tooth loss(1)Assess the patient’s ability to feed himself or herself; is assistance or adaptive feeding equipment required? -Refer to reports of speech-language  pathologist (SLP) regarding swallowing function and aspiration riskDocument level of assistance needed; does the patient currently utilize adaptive toileting equipment?
relevant tests and measures.sensory testing: Assess light touch, pinprick, position sensation (proprioception and kinesthesia), vibration, and temperature –For additional information regarding assessment and treatment of sensory processing disorders, see Clinical Review…Pediatrics ; Topic ID Number
relevant tests and measures.special tests specific to diagnosis: Special tests specific to diagnosis –Vineland Adaptive Behavior Scales (V ABS) -Formal assessment of adaptive behavior assessing domains of communication, daily living, socialization, and motor skills -Normed for children aged 0 to 18 years, 11 months
relevant tests and measures.arousal attention cognition: Document the results of any cognitive or neuropsychological testing that has been completed. These tests should be repeated throughout an individual’s development as initial tests can result in normal cognitive scores, but as the person ages the development slows and deficits become  apparent.(7) Individuals with KS typically have some degree of intellectual disability; however, there are documented case studies of individuals with KS who have normal levels of intelligence(2)

other: Only those contraindications/precautions applicable to this diagnosis are mentioned below, including with regards to modalities. Rehabilitation professionals should always use their professional judgment

Patients with this diagnosis are at risk for falls; follow facility protocols for fall prevention and post fall-prevention instructions at bedside, if inpatient. Ensure that patient and family/caregivers are aware of the potential for falls and educated about fall-prevention  strategies. Discharge criteria should include independence with fall-prevention strategies

To ensure relevance and appropriateness of treatment programs, decisions about goals and the course of therapy should be made in collaboration with the patient, caregivers, and other healthcare professionals. It is highly recommended that family members be involved in the rehabilitation process as much as possible
Clinician should carefully consider the patient’s stamina and medical status before beginning therapy
Cultural background, language preference, and patient interests must be considered when planning treatment goals and activities

Clinicians should follow the guidelines of their clinic/hospital and what is ordered by the patient’s physician. The summary below is meant to serve as a guide, not to replace orders from a physician or a clinic’s specific protocols

assessment plan of care.diagnosis need for treatment: An occupational therapist (OT) will determine if an individual with KS who has functional deficits as a result of the physical and cognitive impairments associated with the syndrome is an appropriate candidate for occupational therapy following the completion of a thorough evaluation
assessment plan of care.rule out: Prior to diagnosing KS, the patient’s medical team will rule out other possible disorders/syndromes, including Turner syndrome(1) Velocardiofacial syndrome (VCFS)(1) CHARGE syndrome(2) 22q11 deletion syndrome(2) IRF6-related  disorders(2) Branchiootorenal (BOR) syndrome(2) Ehlers-Danlos  syndrome(2) Larsen syndrome(2) Hardikar syndrome(2) Van der Woude syndrome(26)
assessment plan of care.referral to other disciplines: Because KS affects multiple systems of the body and each individual is affected differently throughout the lifespan, appropriate referrals to other disciplines is extremely important(1) Gastroenterologist for gastrointestinal issues such as GER, chronic diarrhea, constipation, etc.(1) Cardiologist for cardiac abnormalities/congenital heart defects(1) ENT and/or cleft/plastic surgeon in the case of cleft palate, SMCP, VPD, or lip pits(1,2) Neurologist for individuals with CNS malformation(s) and/or seizure activity(2) Audiologist and/or ENT for ear and hearing assessment due to increased risk of both conductive and sensorineural hearing loss(1) Ophthalmologist for eye problems and infections(1) Physical therapist (PT) for evaluation and treatment due to hypotonia, musculoskeletal issues, and gross motor/ developmental delays(1) SLP for evaluation and treatment due to speech, language, and swallowing/feeding impairments(1) Endocrinologist for issues related to growth and hypoglycemia(1) Orthopedic surgeon for scoliosis, hip dislocation due to joint laxity, and other musculoskeletal issues(1) Immunologist for issues related to immunity or autoimmune disease(1)  Urologist and/or nephrologist for issues related to urinary tract/renal malformations(2) Dentist to ensure early and regular dental examinations and cleaning(1,2) Genetic counselor for testing and family education(1,2) Mental health professional and/or social work for psychosocial issues

maintenance or prevention: There is no known means of preventing KS
Early identification and intervention generally allows for the best functional outcome for individuals with congenital syndromes
patient education: The Kabuki Syndrome Network (KSN) is based in Canada and operated by parents of children with KS; it provides information and support for families affected by KS at https://kabukisyndrome.com/
Netwerk Kabuki Syndroom is a Dutch patient support group that provides information for parents and organizes meetings for families affected by KS: http://www.kabukisyndroom.nl/ Note
